thread.title: atroughton published Will Jamie Vardy's autobiography From Nowhere: My Story top...
thread.title_full: atroughton published Will Jamie Vardy's autobiography From Nowhere: My Story top...

author: atroughton
title: atroughton published Will Jamie Vardy's autobiography From Nowhere: My Story top...
text:
Comments (0) 
Leicester City star Jamie Vardy is going to have overcome all the odds again to claim the Christmas number one bestseller spot in the book chart. 
The 29-year-old England striker's autobiography, From Nowhere: My Story, was officially launched yesterday but is up against stiff competition. 
TV chef Jamie Oliver is to put out his latest cookbook soon in a bid to claim the festive top spot for the fourth time. 
Great British Bake Off star Mary Berry's Sunday Lunches offering and Dan Brown's latest thriller Origin will be in the mix. 
The perennial favourite the Guinness World Records and books by comics Miranda Hart and Alan Carr are also tipped to be popular stocking fullers. 
Read more: Where you can buy a signed copy of Jamie Vardy's autobiography in Leicestershire 
Bookmakers William Hill have sent the Mercury a rundown on the possible top runners. 
The speculative odds (not available to place money on) have Jamie Oliver and Mary Berry joint favourites at 2-1. 
They have put Jamie Vardy a long way back at 33-1 to be number one. 
William Hill's Joe Crilly said: "Over his entire career, Jamie Vardy has made a habit of upsetting the odds and he will have to do so again if he is to grab the Christmas number one spot." 
The odds show Dan Brown at 3-1, the Guinness Book at 5-1, Miranda Hart Peggy at 8-1 and Me and Alan Carr Inside Out 10-1. 
The book industry has dubbed October 20 as Super Thursday because it is the release date for Jamie Oliver's Christmas Cookbook. 
Rock star Phil Collins's autobiography Not Dead Yet and Betrayal, the latest thriller by Martina Cole, the queen of crime drama, have also been held back for release on that date. 
Kiera O'Brien, charts and data editor at The Bookseller, said: "The market has been up all year thanks to J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. 
"There are so many good books out for Christmas it looks like it's going to be a big one." 
"Jamie Oliver has a history of topping the Christmas charts but we also expect the new Ladybirds for Grown Ups titles released on Super Thursday to do very well." 
Bruce Springsteen topped this week's charts with his memoir Born to Run, which sold 37,518 copies. 
TV's former political interrogator-in-chief Jeremy Paxman and Tory bigwig Ken Clarke also put their books out yesterday. 
A Life In Questions, Paxman's long-awaited and typically frank autobiography is out, as is Clarke's memoirs Kind of Blue: A Political Memoir, covering the Conservative minister's long and colourful career. 
Politics sections are also bulging with quick-turnaround Brexit titles including the inside account by Craig Oliver, David Cameron's director of communications, as well as the latest diaries from his Labour Downing Street predecessor, Alastair Campbell. 
Comedian David Walliams unveils his latest children's book, There's A Snake in my School. 
Graham Norton's debut novel Holding, a well-received murder-mystery set in his native Ireland, also hit the stores yesterday.
